page.title: 04The Wells in Swindon
page.content: Swindon was originally part of the Royal Forest of Kinver. Wild pigs were bred for hunting, hence the name {Swin}don. Later the land passed into the ownership of the Earl of Dudley and was divided into farms. Each farm had its own well. Most of these had a hand-pump which pumped water into a stone trough. The village well is over 200 years old. It is in the Holloway opposite the Green Man Pub. Unlike the farm wells it did not draw water from under the ground but was fed by a spring which ran into the back. This is like the Derbyshire wells. It stopped being used in 1905, not 1902 which the sign next to it says. Piped water had to be brought into the village because the wells were becoming contaminated because of the works and were running dry.
